text: A recently validated algorithm for detecting and tracking tropical cyclones (TCs) in coarse resolution climate models was applied to a selected group of 12 models from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5) to assess potential changes in TC track characteristics in the Southern Hemisphere (SH) due to greenhouse warming. Current-climate simulations over the period 1970-2000 are first evaluated against observations using measures of TC genesis location and frequency, as well as track trajectory and lifetime in seven objectively defined genesis regions. The 12-model (12-M) ensemble showed substantial skill in reproducing a realistic TC climatology over the evaluation period. To address potential biases associated with model interdependency, analyses were repeated with an ensemble of five independent models (5-M). Results from both the 12-M and 5-M ensembles were very similar, instilling confidence in the models for climate projections if the current TC-climate relationship is to remain stationary. Projected changes in TC track density between the current-and futureclimate (2070-2100) simulations under the Representatives Concentration 8.5 Pathways (RCP8.5) are also assessed. Overall, projection results showed a substantial decrease (~ 1-3 per decade) in track density over most parts of the SH by the end of the twenty-first century. This decrease is attributed to a significant reduction in TC numbers (~ 15-42%) consistent with changes in large-scale environmental parameters such as relative vorticity, environmental vertical wind shear and relative humidity. This study may assist with adaption pathways and implications for regional-scale climate change for vulnerable regions in the SH.

The frequency of tropical cyclone (TC) impacts on coastal communities are directly determined by the annual number and mean trajectory of localized TCs. Improving clarity of the relationship between these characteristics and humaninduced global warming can therefore help target future planning and preparation efforts to high-risk areas in the Southern Hemisphere (SH). Potential changes to future TC track densities will have regional-scale consequences to communities situated among the three TC basins in the SH, namely the South Indian basin (0-50°S; 30-90°E), the Australian region (0-50°S; 90-160°E) and the southwest Pacific basin (0-50°S; 160°E -120°W).
Determinants of TC track density can be separated into two components: TC genesis (both location and frequency), and TC track direction. A number of previous studies undertaken on TC frequency projections in the SH (e.g., Murakami et al. 2012; Sugi and Yoshimura 2012; Tory et al. 2013c; Rathmann et al. 2014 ) have generally indicated a mild decrease in the hemisphere-wide numbers with reasonably high confidence. However, an exception was a downscaling effort (Emanuel 2013 ) that found an increase in TC activity in the South Indian and western Australian regions. In contrast to TC frequency, there has been little consensus on TC track projections for the SH basins (Christensen et al. 2013; Walsh et al. 2016) , potentially due to relatively 1 3 fewer studies in these basins and a focus on the Northern Hemisphere in recent years (e.g., Camargo 2013; Colbert et al. 2015; Daloz et al. 2015; Wang and Wu 2015; Kossin et al. 2016; Nakamura et al. 2017; Park et al. 2017 ). This highlights the need for more robust quantitative assessments of projected changes in TC track densities for the SH basins using new and innovative approaches.
Recently, attention has begun to shift towards TC track projections as numerous modelling and analytical techniques have been developed and refined to better evaluate the complexities of TC tracks in climate models. This includes improvements in the often-used climate models from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (such as CMIP5, Taylor et al. 2012 ) in reproducing realistic large-scale environmental conditions that affect TC formation [e.g., Climate Change in Australia (CCiA) 2015; Moise et al. 2015; Chand et al. 2017] and advances in track analysis techniques (e.g., Gaffney 2004; Nakamura et al. 2009 Nakamura et al. , 2017 Shen et al. 2018 ). There have also been substantial improvements in detection (and tracking) of TCs in climate models, including the Okubo-Weiss-Zeta scheme (OWZ; Tory et al. 2013a ) that can circumvent detector dependence on model resolution, which is often cited as a limitation of TC projection studies (e.g., Walsh et al. 2007; Horn et al. 2014; Daloz et al. 2015) . The primary aim of this study is to use stateof-the-art analysis techniques to determine if a consensus on track density changes can be achieved for the SH using CMIP5 models under a high emission scenario (RCP8.5; Sect. 2). The two main aspects of TC track density changes (i.e. frequency and track direction) are investigated in seven separate study regions that are objectively identified by a cluster analysis.
The TC detection and tracking scheme of Tory et al. (2013a) is applied to CMIP5 models after having undergone scrupulous validation in ERA-Interim data in terms of annual numbers (Tory et al. 2013b ) and tracks (Bell et al. 2018) . The latter study provided an objective definition of a "TC track" for applications in coarse resolution model data and also recommended discarding short lived TCs (≤ 2-days) for optimal performance. Prior application of the scheme in CMIP5 models (e.g., Tory et al. 2013c; Chand et al. 2017) found that some models failed to realistically simulate a reasonable global climatology of TCs, thus limiting the present study to only the 12 CMIP5 models that were deemed satisfactory by those studies. Moreover, when interpreting results from multi-model ensembles, we also acknowledge the concerns raised by Sanderson et al. (2015) that statistical interdependence between CMIP5 models needs to be considered.
The outline of this paper is as follows. Section 2 contains the data, definitions and methods used in the study. Section 3 provides assessment and validation of models and climate projection results. Section 4 discusses the physical mechanisms that drive significant projected changes in TC track densities. Finally, a summary, discussion of results and prospects of future work are given in Sect. 5.

The International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS-WMO v03r08, Knapp et al. 2010 ) data is used to define the observed TC track climatology and to give a baseline of TC characteristics. For the purpose of this study, an observed TC track is defined to begin at the location the storm first reaches a 10-min sustained wind speed of 17 m s −1 , with storms not reaching this intensity at any time of their lifetime excluded from the analysis. Because of this intensity-based definition, observed TCs were only used over a reliable observational period 1989-2013 (see Klotzbach and Landsea 2015) . Tracks are terminated if a forecast centre no longer tracks them (i.e. track information ceases in the database) or if they encounter an objectively diagnosed subtropical jet (Tory and Dare 2015) after which the storm has likely to have lost its physical TC characteristics.

Twelve models from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project phase 5 (CMIP5, Taylor et al. 2012 ) are used in this study ( Table 1 ). Note that CMIP5 experiments contain the current generation of climate models that provide a wide array of platforms to test current and future climate scenarios (e.g., Knutti et al. 2013) . The two scenarios assessed in this work are (1) the current-climate simulation over the period 1970-2000 for model evaluation and assessment, and (2) the future-climate simulation over the period 2070-2100 under the Representative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (RCP8.5) for projection analyses. RCP8.5 represents an 8.5 W m −2 increase in radiative forcing values in the year 2100 as compared to the pre-industrial emission levels (Riahi et al. 2011) and was chosen to best elucidate any changing TC behaviour in a warmer climate.

Differences between model physics parameterisations, as well as deficiencies in models' ability to resolve atmospheric processes, can create potential biases in the results of projection analyses. In this study, we statistically reduce some of these biases by combining results of all models together to form a multi-model ensemble. In the analysis, results are considered statistically robust if large proportions of models agree on the sign and magnitude of the change. A statistical significance test to evaluate the robustness is determined at the 95% level and is based on a binomial distribution (e.g., Chand et al. 2017) . Thus for a 12-model ensemble, the number of models required to attain the 95% level of significance is 10. However, this test assumes model independence, and based on the analysis of Knutti et al. (2013) and Sanderson et al. (2015) , some models may be in violation of this assumption. As a result, we additionally employed a smaller set of independent models for all our analyses (see Appendix 1 for details). This "smaller" multi-model ensemble is comprised of five models and requires all models to agree on the sign of change to achieve the 95% significance.

The OWZ TC detection and tracking scheme (Tory et al. 2013a ) is used in this study to detect and track TCs in all models. The OWZ scheme has undergone scrupulous validation in reanalysis data in terms of annual TC numbers and genesis positions (Tory et al. 2013b ) and more recently in terms of tracks at 12-h intervals (Bell et al. 2018) . Key details of the OWZ detector and tracker are provided in Tory et al. (2013a) while a short summary of the scheme is provided in the appendix of this paper for easy reference (Appendix 2).
Crucially, the Bell et al. (2018) track validation study identified a limitation of the tracking scheme, in that it detected a higher than expected frequency of short duration TC tracks in ERA-Interim. This limitation also affected TC tracks in models (Fig. 1) , and so necessary steps are taken to minimise its impact on projection results following the analysis of Bell et al. (2018) , who showed that most of the short lifetime tracks (≤ 48-h) in models were likely to be associated with detector related errors. As such, TC tracks less than 2-days in lifetime are removed from the analysis to achieve a more accurate climatology.
To be consistent with the definition of the observed TC tracks, the objective TC track definition established in Bell et al. (2018) is also used here. This definition states that a TC track detected by the OWZ scheme commences from the TC declaration location 1 and terminates where a TC either dissipates or encounters an objectively diagnosed subtropical jet.

The probabilistic curve-clustering technique of Gaffney (2004) is used to group TC tracks of similar properties in space and time over the entire SH. TCs in certain subregions with more erratic tracks have undergone further cluster analysis to elucidate more meaningful patterns (see Sect. 3). We note that when comparing TC number results in different climate scenarios, changing orientations of corresponding clusters could mask actual changes (or even produce spurious results), making comparisons difficult. This issue is further exacerbated by the large geographical size of the study area under consideration and the high number of clusters used.
Therefore, we decided to use the clustering results from the observations to define geographically consistent regions for ease of comparison. That is, we use the 75% genesis contour of each cluster in IBTrACS to define consistent regions for the entire experiment (including models) instead of reclustering each new set of model data. Given that clusters are largely adjacent to each other across the hemisphere, simple meridional lines were used to define the seven regions (R1-R7, Fig. 2 ). The positions of the meridional lines were carefully chosen and adjusted to achieve as distinct regions as possible, including taking into consideration the general track type of TCs in neighbouring clusters.
3 Evaluation and projection of TC track density change

section_title: Regional genesis density and TC numbers
text:
Changes in TC track density are dependent on both TC numbers (also used interchangeably with genesis frequency throughout the paper) and track directions. We start by evaluating the ability of the 12 CMIP5 models (hereafter collectively referred to as the 12-M ensemble) to simulate regional scale (R1-R7) TC genesis locations and frequencies in the SH. It is evident from the analysis that the 12-M CMIP5 models can realistically simulate spatial patterns of the observed genesis density estimates reasonably well in most regions (Fig. 2) . However, an exception is the eastern South Pacific region (i.e. farther east of R7) where a number of TCs are detected by the models that were not present in the observations, as also noted in prior studies (e.g., Tory et al. 2013d; Chand et al. 2017 ). This could be potentially due to climate model biases in simulating an overly zonal orientation of the South Pacific Convergence Zone (SPCZ) 3 in the eastern Pacific (e.g., Brown et al. 2012; Grose et al. 2014 ). In addition, Tory and Ye (2018) investigated the different constraints that restrict TC formation in a selection of CMIP5 models. They found these models were unable to correctly simulate the cool sea-surface temperatures and associated dry middle troposphere that inhibits TC formation in this region. The average annual number of TCs detected by the 12-M ensemble in current-climate simulation was also found to compare well with the observed climatology (Table 2) . However, some slight overestimations were noted, particularly near Madagascar (R1) where an additional ~ 2 TCs per year were detected. We next turn our attention to regional projections of TC numbers between the current-and future-climate simulations from the CMIP5 models (Table 2 ; Fig. 3 ). Results indicate a widespread reduction of TC detections by the late twentyfirst century, particularly in the South Indian basin (i.e., regions R1-R4). Here, each region experiences a statistically significant reduction in mean climatological numbers (at the 95% significance level), with the largest reduction (~ 42%) occurring in R3 located between 85°E and 105°E. The region north of Australia (R5) experiences about a 15% reduction in TC numbers (though this is not statistically significant), while there is no clear indication of any change off the east coast of Australia (R6). Farther east into the South Pacific (R7), a statistically significant reduction in TC numbers (~ 15%) is also found.
We recognize that some models used in these analyses (12-M ensemble) are very similar in physical characteristics and that model interdependence may complicate the interpretation of multi-model ensemble results (Knutti et al. 2013; Sanderson et al. 2015) . For this reason, as well as to correct model biases in reproducing TC climatology in the SH (e.g., detections east of R7), our analyses were repeated with a 5-model (5-M) ensemble. Details on the selection of these five models, based on independence (Knutti et al. 2013 ) and a number of other criteria for statistical bias corrections, can be found in Appendix 1. Overall, projection results from the 5-M ensemble were very similar with the 12-M results (Table 2; Fig. 3 ), extending confidence to the 12-M results.

The second aspect of track density change analyzed is the frequency and direction of TC tracks. Here we evaluate the ability of the chosen five independent CMIP5 models (5-M ensemble) to simulate these track characteristics in each region (R1-R7) of the SH. It is important to emphasize that within some regions (R3-R7), there exists distinct westward and eastward trajectories that are not well captured by the seven mean trajectories (as in Fig. 2) . Therefore, we sub-divide these regions by implementing a further cluster analysis with respect to two clusters in an attempt to separate the tracks into two distinct types: eastward and westward moving tracks (Figs. 4, 5, 6) . 4 Regional track characteristics are then evaluated with measures of mean track trajectory, mean TC lifetime and the number of eastward and westward moving tracks.
The mean direction of TC tracks detected by the 5-M ensemble in current climate simulations were found to compare quite well with the observed climatology (Figs. 4, 5, 6 ). However, the mean TC trajectory lengths were often slightly underestimated in models, for example in R1 and R6-East, potentially due to biases in estimating endpoints of tracks both in observations and models. In contrast to the latter result, the mean TC lifetimes were well simulated in most regions (Table 4) , and we note that underestimated TC trajectory lengths were attributed to a slight underestimation of model tracks in the region poleward of 30°S (not shown) rather than underestimated lifetimes. The observed ratios between westward and eastward TC tracks in R3, R5, R6 and R7 were found to compare well with the current-climate 5-M simulations (Table 3 ). However, we note an overestimation of the model simulated westward tracks in R4 (where 48% tracked westward), causing a discrepancy with observations (where just 18% tracked westward).
We next examine projected changes in the tracks between the current-climate and future-climate (under RCP8.5) conditions (far right panel in Figs. 4, 5, 6 ). For ease of comparison, the 5-M ensemble mean trajectories for the current-("black tracks") and future-("red tracks") climate simulations are plotted on the same axis (Fig. 7) . Overall, some small shifts in mean genesis locations (circles) are noted (e.g., poleward movement in R2, R3, R4 and R6-West under RCP8.5; see also Kossin et al. 2014; Moon et al. 2015) . For the mean trajectories, there seems to be no clear deviation between the current and future climate simulations, although one exception appears to be the trajectory of R6-West. This trajectory appears to shift from west-southwest in the current-climate to more southwestward in the future-climate, potentially shifting mean TC landfall positions farther south over the eastern coast of Australia (see also Fig. 5, . Furthermore, projected changes in TC numbers are also compared for the eastward and westward trajectories defined earlier (for regions R3-R7; Table 3 ). The significant decrease of TC numbers in the central South Indian (R3) was found to more heavily reduce the eastward tracks (65%) than the westward tracks (39%). The decrease in TC numbers over northern Australia (R5) was found to reduce the westward track numbers by 33%, yet the number of eastward tracks was found to increase by 6% (although the change in the latter was not considered statistically significant). Westward TC tracks in the Coral Sea region (R6) were found to increase by 16%, with region wide numbers offset by an accompanying decrease in eastward numbers (13%). Farther into the South Pacific (R7), projected decreases in TC numbers were more evenly spread across the different track types (Table 3) . For completeness, projected changes in mean TC track lifetimes were also examined (Table 4 ) but no major changes (> 1-day) were noted.

The prior sections have separately given detailed analyses of the two aspects of TC track density changes between the current-and future-climate model simulations. Here, we combine these two aspects into a single measure called "TC activity" that can collectively explain changes in TC track density under the RCP8.5 scenario. TC activity is measured by accumulating the number of unique TCs either forming or entering a 2.5° x 2.5° grid box over the entire SH basin for both current-and future-climate simulations using the 12-M ensemble of CMIP5 models (Fig. 8) . TC activity is found to decrease significantly (up to 3 TCs per decade) throughout the South Indian basin extending through to 135°E (i.e. including R1-R4, and R5-West) in the future-climate. The decrease in TC activity is most concentrated centrally in the basin (R3), occurring over the open ocean. However, the coastal communities of east Africa, Madagascar and western Australian region are likely to experience a similar decrease in activity (~ 1-2 per decade). Overall, these decreases are likely from the significant decreases in TC numbers over those regions (Sect. 3.1) rather than projected changes in track directions that showed little deviation (Sect. 3.2).
East of 135°E, projected changes in TC activity are comparatively smaller in magnitude (mostly within ± 1 TC per decade). Notably, the small patch of increased TC activity alongside the eastern coast of Australia is supported by significant agreement between individual models of the 12-M ensemble (not shown). TC activity here is influenced by the number and mean trajectory of TCs in the R5-East and R6-West sub-clusters. In R6-West, TC numbers were found to slightly increase in magnitude for both the 12-M and 5-M ensembles (Table 3 ). The mean trajectory of R6-West was also found to move more favourably into this patch of increased density (Fig. 7) . However, the combination of these effects only amounts to a very small increase in the coastal TC activity (~ 1 per 20 years). Furthermore, it is beyond the scope of this study to attribute poleward or other shifts in track density to climate change as it may require complicated downscaling techniques (e.g., Walsh and Katzfey 2000; Emanuel 2013) . East of the dateline (R7), TC activity was generally found to decrease (~ 1 per decade) and was attributed to decreasing TC numbers in this region as also noted in several other previous studies (e.g., Tory et al. 2013c ).

As seen earlier, substantial changes in TC activity between the current-climate simulation and future-climate RCP8.5 simulation were attributed to changes in TC numbers rather than tracks. Therefore, the large-scale environmental parameters associated with TC formation are empirically analysed here to better understand these projected changes. TC formation is controlled by a set of dynamic and thermodynamic environmental parameters (e.g., Gray 1975; Tory and Frank 2010) , noting that not all of these parameters may be relevant on climate time scales. The dynamic parameters evaluated include relative vorticity at 850 hPa, environmental vertical wind shear between 850 and 200 hPa and low-level convergence at 850 hPa. The only thermodynamic parameter evaluated is mid-level relative humidity at 700 hPa. Values of large-scale fields (such as u and v components of winds at respective levels) needed to compute these parameters are taken during the peak of the SH TC season (i.e. December-February), and then composited over all models in consideration to form multi-model ensembles for the current-and future-climate simulations (Figs. 9, 10) .
To a large extent, all large-scale environmental parameters exhibit less favourable future conditions for TC development in the South Indian Ocean (west of 130°E; regions R1-R4) where models project a strong reduction in climatological numbers between the current-and future-climate (Fig. 3) . Cyclonic relative vorticity (negative in the SH) is reduced in the main genesis zone (~ 8-15°S), particularly evident in R1 around Madagascar, and appears to be the main factor inhibiting TC development here in the future climate (Figs. 9a,  10a where positive difference indicates suppressed vorticity). Reduced mid-level relative humidity (Figs. 9c, 10c) , as well as reduced low-level convergence (Fig. 9d) , are also consistent with a reduction in TC numbers.
In R5 north of Australia (~ 130-155°E), we see a slight enhancement of cyclonic vorticity (Figs. 9a, 10a) , particularly near the east Australian coast (~ 140°E, 12°S). While these conditions should favour development of TCs, we suspect that projected decline in the number of TCs in this region is strongly modulated by substantially reduced lowlevel convergence (Fig. 9d) and to a lesser extent by relative humidity (Fig. 10c) . In the two South Pacific regions (R6 and R7; 155°E-135°W), increased environmental vertical wind shear (Fig. 9b) , and to a lesser extent reduced low-level relative vorticity and convergence (Fig. 9a, d ), appear to be the main factors inhibiting TC formation.

A comprehensive study was undertaken in the SH to examine the likely projected changes in TC track densities due to anthropogenic greenhouse warming. Climate model simulations from the CMIP5 experiments were used to assess changes in TC track densities between the current and future-climates (2070-2100). Two multi-model ensembles were used, a 12-M and a 5-M version, with the latter only containing models that met more strict criteria such as model independence.
Unlike previous climate projection studies for the SH basins, we have objectively created seven regions (R1-R7) based on cluster analysis where each region is characteristically distinct in terms of mean genesis location and track shapes. After robust statistical assessment and validation of TC numbers and tracks for each region using observed records from the IBTrACS database, CMIP5 simulations from the current-climate were compared with those from the future-climate (under RCP8.5) to examine the influence of increasing atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations on regional scale TC characteristics in the SH basins. The major findings of this work are summarised as follows. • Compared to observations, CMIP5 models can realistically simulate regional TC numbers and tracks reasonably well in the SH.
• TC track density was projected to decrease (~ 1-3 per decade) by the late twenty-first century for coastal communities situated in the South Indian Ocean and Western Australia. This was attributed to a significant decrease in TC numbers west of 130°E (~ 18-42%; R1-R4) due to changes in environmental parameters such as reduced relative humidity, relative vorticity and convergence.
• TC track density change over eastern Australia and the Coral Sea was found to be fairly minor (within ± 1 TC per decade). Notably, poleward of 20°S on the eastern Australian coast, there was significant agreement between models of a small increase in track density (~ 1 per 20 years). This could be potentially due to an increase in the number of Coral Sea storms tracking westward (R6-West), increased lifetime of R5-East storms, or change in mean trajectory of R6-West storms.
• Over the South Pacific (R7), a decrease in TC track density was found (~ 1 per decade). This was attributed to a significant decrease in TC numbers (~ 15%), consistent with increased environmental vertical wind shear, and to a lesser extent, reduced low-level cyclonic vorticity and convergence.
• Projected changes in the mean lifetime of TC tracks in each region were also examined but no indication of any major change (> 1 day) between current-and future-climate simulations were established.
Overall, the projections of annual TC numbers given by this study are consistent with finer resolution (60 km) model experiments performed by Murakami et al. (2012) as they also showed a more confident reduction in TC numbers over the South Indian Ocean than the South Pacific (as per their Fig. 4) . Using coarser resolution model experiments, Rathmann et al. (2014) also showed similar results, emphasising that the significant decrease of TCs in the South Indian Ocean under RCP8.5 was consistent with more frequent early twentieth century TCs. Similar to the present study, Sugi et al. (2014) attributed a less favourable large-scale environment to the widespread reduction of TC numbers in the South Indian Ocean. Our result of no major changes in TC track lifetimes was consistent with the results of Knutson et al. (2010) but in contrast to Rathmann et al. (2014) who projected TC lifetimes in the SP basin (i.e. in our R5-R7 regions) to decrease by 19%.
Although not covered in this paper, the importance of TC intensity projections cannot be understated, noting the future trend of intense TCs may not follow the trend of overall TC activity. A metric for TC activity that encapsulates intensity and is used in seasonal forecasting is the Accumulated Cyclone Energy (Bell and Chelliah 2006) , however downscaling intensity projections was deemed beyond the scope of this paper.
Other areas of scientific interest suggested by this study include: (1) the extent at which projected changes are modulated by the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) (2) quantitative assessment of the drivers of eastward and westward tracks in the regions R3-R6 with respect to natural modes such as monsoonal waves and ENSO, and (3) further investigation into the cause of a slight increase in TC activity poleward of 20°S on the eastern Australian coast.
